node.title: Define Material as a Function
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am sure there must be some instructions somewhere. But I want to define a function for the material properties. For example, this is my original input file:
[Materials]
  [elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 25e9
    poissons_ratio = 0.25
  []
  [stress]
    type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
  []
[]

Now I want the "youngs_modulus" and "poissons_ratio" to be a function of x, y, and z.
Fox example, "youngs_modulus  = a2 * exp(a1 / sqrt(x^2+y^2+z^2))". And "a1, a2" are constants.
I failed with "parsedFunction" material.
Thank you very much!
-Y

Hello
You ll want to use this material instead
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/ComputeVariableIsotropicElasticityTensor.html
and use a ParsedMaterial to set the Young Modulus and Poisson ratio
Guillaume

When I use

[Materials]
  [elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeVariableIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = youngs_modulus
    poissons_ratio = poissons_ratio
    args = x
  []
  [youngs_modulus]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    expression = '3*x'
  []
  [poissons_ratio]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    expression = '1-exp(1/x)'
  []
  [stress]
    type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
  []
[]

It shows:
elasticity_tensor: Coupled variable 'x' was not found
Thank you!
Here is the problem, I am working on.

When I use

[Materials]
  [elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeVariableIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = youngs_modulus
    poissons_ratio = poissons_ratio
    args = x
  []
  [youngs_modulus]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    expression = '3*x'
  []
  [poissons_ratio]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    expression = '1-exp(1/x)'
  []
  [stress]
    type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
  []
[]

It shows: elasticity_tensor: Coupled variable 'x' was not found
Thank you!

because args only is coupled variable.

x is not a variable
Can you enter a dummy variable as args?
to define one:
[AuxVariables]
  [dummy]
  []
[]

I am also attaching the input file for a study with homogeneous material properties.
Thank you!
Archive.zip

x is not a variable Can you enter a dummy variable as args? to define one:
[AuxVariables]
  [dummy]
  []
[]


But how to link this dummy variable to x?

x is position right?
Or are you trying to use a variable for x ??
If so then you need to be using the name of that variable when defining the ParsedMaterial, not x

Yes! Please see the problem set here:

Here is the problem, I am working on.

ok then define temperature as an auxiliary variable.
Then use a ParsedAux to set it s spatial program.
And for Young Modulus and Poisson ratio, use ParsedMaterial with the expression of T
add coupled_variables = 'T' to the ParsedMarerial parameters

It looks not very straightforward. I would appreciate it if you could show me how to modify my input file. Thank you very much!

I am also attaching the input file for a study with homogeneous material properties.
Thank you!
Archive.zip

this question i do . you can use like this( it may be redundancy）
[Materials]
  [elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = youngs_modulus
    poissons_ratio = 0.25
  []
  [youngs_modulus]
     type = ParsedMaterial
      expression = '3*x'  # such like this
  []
[]

no you cant do that
ParsedMaterial will define a property called F by default, not Young modulus

Sorry, I used do it in HeatConduction , and the theraml_conductiivty is myseilf define material. But when i try to use this don't know args to set what.
[Materials]
  [elsticity_tensor]
     type = ComputeVaribleIsotropicElasticityTensor
     youngs_modulus = youngs_modulus
     poissons_ratio = 0.2
     args = ?
  []
  [youngs_modulus]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    expression = 3600*(1+x)
    property_name = youngs_modulus
  []
[]

I have try use function in 'ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor', but the youngs_modulus type is only double

node.title: CARDINAL wrapper installation.
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I am trying to install CARDINAL wrapper for using MOOSE and NEKS. When I run the command
./contrib/moose/scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh
I receive this error:

What does the community recommend?

Can you attach the configure.log file? It should exist at:
/mnt/d/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/configure.log

Also, in the future it would help if you refrained from posting images of text. The issue doing so, is that the search functionality on "Discussions" is unable to parse the information in an image. Thanks!

Okay, I will do that from now on thank you for education me on that issue. Thank you for taking a look at this issue, here is the co
configure_log.txt

@milljm , I managed to get past this part of the CARDINAL installation last week. However, I ran out of storage during the installation and had to uninstall and re-install WSL/Ubuntu onto a different drive. I am wondering if I am missing and ubuntu packages that might correct this error..
What version of Ubuntu are you using?

I am looking through your log, and I notice you are using perhaps some of our environment (The moose-mpich conda environment perhaps?)
Are you following these instructions: https://cardinal.cels.anl.gov/with_conda.html
(you're only after OpenMC, and therefore you should not be trying to build PETSc)
Or are you instead needing to build without using Conda: https://cardinal.cels.anl.gov/without_conda.html
(you need to install all the compilers yourself using your systems package management)

I was able build PETSc, running the moose/scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh, after performing the following apt-get commands on fresh install of Ubuntu 22.04. These are similar commands we use to initiate a fresh machine for use within our build farm.
My advice, is to run these only in a new WSL container... I have no idea what havoc these commands might do in a WSL environment you've already established.
    apt-get update
    apt-get -y --allow-unauthenticated upgrade
    apt-get -y --allow-unauthenticated install software-properties-common
    apt-get -y --allow-unauthenticated install build-essential debootstrap vim emacs gfortran libperl-dev python3-dev python3 file flex bison autoconf automake curl libtirpc-dev git procps unzip python3-yaml gcc-11 g++-11 gfortran-11 cpp-11 libx11-dev libxt-dev libglpk-dev rsync
    apt-get -y remove gcc-12 g++-12 gfortran-12 cpp-12
    apt-get -y autoremove
    apt-get -y clean
    apt-get -y autoclean
    update-alternatives --install /usr/bin/gcc gcc /usr/bin/gcc-11 100
    update-alternatives --install /usr/bin/g++ g++ /usr/bin/g++-11 100
    update-alternatives --install /usr/bin/gfortran gfortran /usr/bin/gfortran-11 100
    update-alternatives --install /usr/bin/cpp cpp /usr/bin/cpp-11 100

    # Installs OpenMPI, Cmake
    apt-get install libopenmpi-dev cmake python3-packaging pkg-config

    # Makes `python` default to `python3` (probably only valid on Ubuntu 22.04!)
    update-alternatives --install /usr/bin/python python /usr/bin/python3.10 2
    update-alternatives --install /usr/bin/python3 python3 /usr/bin/python3.10 3

    # Set compilers (you'll need to do this every time you launch your WSL Ubuntu container)
    export CC=mpicc CXX=mpicxx FC=mpif90 F90=mpif90 F77=mpif77
This solved all of my issues! I cannot thank you enough! I am excited to start my research now!
I was missing a few of those packages. I am now able to compile and I successfully ran OpenMC through cardinal

Your very welcome! I think you might like this upcoming process: neams-th-coe/cardinal#594
It was your discussion here that prompted me to "help out" and make some easier Conda available packages for installation =D
I'll post back here when ready. The idea is you'll only need to:
mamba create -n cardinal cardinal
To have OpenMC, MOAB, dagmc, NekRS, and Cardinal installed.
Oooo that will be exciting and very simple. The reason I didn't go through the conda environment is only that I wanted the capability of NEKRS. Thank you for tackling this problem!

node.title: ConstantBoundsAux and Constant/Monomial Nonlinear Variable
node.bodyText:
Hi:
I am using an rDG scheme where my variables are constant/monomial.  I need to limit the range of one nonlinear variable (void fraction).  The ConstantBoundsAux seems perfect for this, but...
It appears that it only works if the nonlinear variable is nodal.  Is there a way to do this for an elemental variable.
Thanks,
Joe Kelly
@joshuahansel

It should be a straight-forward fix. You just need to generalize the BoundsAuxBase to take care of the elemental variable case. For example at https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/framework/src/auxkernels/BoundsAuxBase.C#L48-L49
I can walk you through this if any of you want to take a crack at it.
Wow, that was fast!  And yes, I am afraid that I'll need some help in modifying computeValue().  Thanks.

When I get off work today, I can give you the APIs to look at. Otherwise @GiudGiud may point you to those before I do. This bounds magic essentially boils down to figuring out the corresponding dof number of the nonlinear variable bounded_variable at the given node/element.
That would be great.  Thanks again.
I can give it a shot this afternoon
Thanks @GiudGiud
Thanks @GiudGiud

@joe61vette Were you running into some cases that produced negative void fractions, or were you just being proactive? I don't recall fighting with negative values (just phase disappearance) since moving from CG to rDG, so it might be difficult for me to test this out (at least with the systems/formulations I work with).

Unfortunately, I can get negative void fractions and it is hard to recover from them.  I have "protected" my kernels and constitutive models by using the void fraction as a material property that is limited between 0 and 1.  But the nonlinear variable can still go negative when I am essentially solving a single-phase problem with the two fluid eqns.  Note, this is a simple air/water test case so no interfacial heat/mass transfer.
I first tried using the BoundingValueElementDamper.  But this quickly went to the minimum damping factor and stopped the problem.  I will give #23449 a try later today (THANKS @GiudGiud!)

Hi Joe,
I'm assuming that you've already looked at https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/ConstantBoundsAux.html, but I just wanted to make sure you saw this part:

the user has to specify the PETSc options -snes_type vinewtonssls or -snes_type vinewtonrsls

I don't have any experience with PETSc's variational inequalities solvers, so I don't know how restrictive this is.
In RELAP-7 and Sockeye, we've come across the issue of bounding volume fractions, and we're using rDG/FV. I've never tried ConstantBoundsAux (I didn't know it existed!). I think for us, the issue was less about negativity of a volume fraction and more about the calculation of fluid properties of the absent/near-absent phase, since the thermodynamic state at which those properties are evaluated is very sensitive at those low volume fractions, and it's easy to go out of the range of validity in the fluid properties packages. I never found a great solution to this - I've tried many and gotten strategies that work well on some problems not work on others. I wish I had more time to explore this topic. Some general principles I tried to follow are:

Start with a spatial discretization/stabilization that theoretically cannot get unphysical values. Of course, for a nonlinear solve, iterates can still be out of physical bounds, so see next bullet.
Make sure the nonlinear residual calculation can handle unphysical values. You can bound the solution variable locally, for instance. This may lead to convergence difficulties due to a discontinuity in the nonlinear residual, so you can attempt to smooth this out with gradual transitions in the quantity/residual.

Even then, you can probably still end up with negative values... In the CG days of RELAP-7, we did this "volume fraction re-mapper" thing, that had mixed success, where we made our solution variable the unbounded void fraction (say, alpha_unbounded), that has a unique mapping to the bounded volume fraction (say, alpha), which is then what gets used in the residuals and such. So you could safely converge to a negative value of alpha_unbounded. Basically, you have alpha_unbounded = alpha for values that are larger than some small number epsilon and then you have a smooth mapping such that the limit of alpha(alpha_unbounded) as alpha_unbounded goes to infinity, is zero. I suspect that this approach brings new issues in this limit, but I don't know them well.
I'm sorry for rambling - it probably wasn't that helpful, since we never were completely successful.
Anyway, I'm interested to see how well ConstantBoundsAux works for you!
-Josh

Thanks Josh.  I figured that between Sockeye and RELAP-7 someone had already solved this.  If I can't figure out how to generalize ConstantBoundsAux to handle elemental variables, then I may have to do something like the mapping approach.  For some of my kernels, like the pressure gradient, I need a positive non-zero value of the phase volume fraction.  I'll let you know how this goes.
Joe

Note that in the worst case you can take a nonlinear iteration per constrained dof to resolve active/inactive sets. As @joshuahansel has mentioned the best case scenario is to use a discretization scheme that is ensured to preserve physicality ... but even then TVD schemes have non-smooth derivatives which are themselves problematic for Newton

node.title: the following blocks (ids) do not exist on the mesh
node.bodyText:
Hello Moosers,
I am trying to define different elastic properties for different elsets (layers); the layers are elsets defined in my mesh file, however i got the error message 👍
the following blocks (ids) do not exist on the mesh 

A block is not an Elset ?
regards,
Sab
Use boundary = elset

I am using this syntax:
[./elasticity_tensor14]
    type = ComputeElasticityTensorCP
   block='c1'   
    C_ijkl = '11e3 12e3 13e3 22e3 23e3 33e3 44e3 55e3 66e3'
    fill_method = symmetric9
    euler_angle_1 = 0.0
    euler_angle_2 = .0
    euler_angle_3 = 0.0
  [../]

where to add  boundary = elset ?
thanks
I may have misunderstood. What does elset mean?
Element set
That sounds like an Abaqus keyword. I think block should work. Someone else more familiar with the Abaqus mesh format may be able to help.

Open your mesh with paraview and look at the blocks in the properties tab on the left. This is what you can use as a 'block'
I m not sure what an element set is wrt MOOSE. Maybe @dschwen
In case paraview doesn't support your mesh format but moose does, you can do my-app-opt -i input.i --mesh-only to generate an exodus file.

Thank, it works fine non.
Regards

Le ven. 17 févr. 2023, 15:53, Gary (Tianchen) Hu ***@***.***>
a écrit :
…
 In case paraview doesn't support your mesh format but moose does, you can
 do my-app-opt -i input.i --mesh-only to generate an exodus file.

 .
 You are receiving this because you authored the thread.Message ID:
 ***@***.***>

node.title: Need some hint to model an Earth Air Heat Exchanger
node.bodyText:
Hello everybody,
I am currently working on an Earth Air Heat Exchanger model: the soil around the pipe is meshed with 3D elements and will solve the soil temperature diffusion (variable "ts"). Inside the pipe, the air is circulating in the direction Z (see figure which is a small part of the entire mesh) and I would like to implement the fluid one dimensional circulation inside the pipe by 1D elements using my own kernels (solving for the air velocity "vz", air pressure "p" and air temperature "ta"). In the air energy equation, associated to the variable "ta", I have a convective term of the form
h ( ta - ts_wall_mean)        with     ts_wall_mean = (1/2pi) integrate (theta=0->2pi) ts dtheta
so I declared "ts" inside the pipe 1D elements. My problem is to implement the constraint between "ts" in the pipe 1D elements and its counterpart in the soil 3D elements so that "ts" in the pipe is the mean value of "ts" around the wall soil boundary. I had a look at LinearNodalConstraint but I am not able to get the nodes id of the pipe wall/soil efficiently.
I successfully merged the soil mesh (from gmsh) and the pipe mesh (from gmsh too) since Moose does not read 1D elements for 3D meshes.
Does anyone can provide me some hint ?

Hello
I think the best option here will be to look at thermal contact options. I m less familiar with them unfortunately.
Without this, or if it doesnt pan out, I would get started with an approach that does not properly compute the Jacobian, and solve with PJFNK, just to get started.
To do that, I would use:

a nearestpointlayeredaverage to get axial averages in the 2D wall of the temperature
a linevaluesampler (or again a layered average) to get the 1D values in the pipe
Then
You can make simple kernels restricted to the relevant elements implementing the convection equation
a regular kernel for the 1D pipe. The nearestpointlayeredaverage will be an input and can return the axially dependent profile
an interface kernel for the 2D elements. You ll have to add additional logic to axially map the linevaluesampler, but a layeredaverage should be able to return the direct value of the pipe temperature.

if this works, great.
If not then we need to consider the Jacobian entries. For this you will need to get the node ids (if they are nodal variables) or generally the dof ids. You ll need to build a user object that examines the mesh and finds the nodes and elements involved in the heat transfer and properly axially indexes them.
Then some constraint will take that list.
Other idea, easier to get started:
instead of a 1D pipe, just make a big 3D pipe, have it part of the 3D mesh and use interface kernels for convection between Ts and Tf
You can still have 1D flow, you ll just have a radial temperature profile in the pipe.
Guillaume

Dear Guillaume,
Thank you for your answer.  I tested a solution close to your first suggestion:
[Variables]
  [ts]
    family = LAGRANGE
    order  = FIRST
    block  = "SOIL"
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
    [ts_wall]
      family = LAGRANGE
      order  = FIRST
      block  = "SOIL"
    []
    [ts_pipe]
      family = LAGRANGE
      order  = FIRST
      block  = "PIPE"
    []
  []

...... materials and kernels.......

[UserObjects]
  [./ts_wall_uo]
    type = LayeredSideAverage
    direction = z
    num_layers = 10
    variable = ts
    execute_on = 'ALWAYS'
    boundary = WALL
  [../]
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./ts_wall_aux]
    type = SpatialUserObjectAux
    variable = ts_wall
    boundary = WALL
    user_object = ts_wall_uo
    execute_on = 'ALWAYS'
  [../]
  [./ts_pipe]
    type = NearestNodeValueAux
    paired_boundary = "WALL"
    paired_variable = ts_wall
    variable = ts_pipe
    execute_on = 'ALWAYS'
    boundary = "PIPE"
  [../]
[]

[VectorPostprocessors]
  [avg]
    type = SpatialUserObjectVectorPostprocessor
    userobject = ts_wall_uo
  []
[]

If the NearestNodeValueAux kernel is commented I correctly get the mean value of ts on the wall, but when I decomment this NearestNodeValueAux, I get the following error
*** ERROR ***
/home/vmagnenet/Projets_Moose/eahe/run/eahe.i:363: (AuxKernels/ts_pipe/boundary):
    the following node sets (ids) do not exist on the mesh: PIPE (8)

because "PIPE" is not a boundary.....  I had a look at  thermal contact but it seems also defined only for surfaces boundaries.
Your second idea (3D pipe) was my first idea ;-) , but I want to use classic fluid correlations for 1D flow in pipes (simplified heat equation with experimental correlations for head loss, convection versus Nusselt and Reynolds etc....) . I keep this solution in mind if the "good" previous approach fails.
Is there any way of creating a nodeset associated to the block of EDGE2 elements of "PIPE" ?

In 1)
You are using an auxiliary variable to store the output of the layered average. You dont need to do this, you can query those values directly in your kernel.
If you want to use an auxiliary variable use a block instead of a boundary restriction. Your mesh is not a boundary for the pipe, it s a block
I m afraid the EDGE2 pipe is currently a block and there is no lower dimensional boundary to create from it within MOOSE
You would have to redo your mesh to make a nodeset as well as a block (to solve equations)

Dear Guillaume,
After a long night making nightmares about MOOSE ;-) I finally found an easy way to get the model work. The air flow is solved in a small layer (called PIPE) and meshed with 3D elements and just near the soil interface (see figure below). To account for the convective term, I developed a small Kernel accounting for the width of the interface (I don't know if this kind of kernel already exists but I prefer having my own one):
Real
EAHE_Interface_Convective_Term::computeQpResidual()
{
  return -_hwall[_qp]*(_u[_qp]-_u_ext[_qp])*_test[_i][_qp]/_width[_qp];
}

Real
EAHE_Interface_Convective_Term::computeQpJacobian()
{
  return -_hwall[_qp]*_phi[_j][_qp]*_test[_i][_qp]/_width[_qp];
}

Real EAHE_Interface_Convective_Term::computeQpOffDiagJacobian(unsigned int jvar)
{
  Real jac=0.0;
  if(jvar==_u_ext_id)
    jac = +_hwall[_qp]*_u_ext_phi[_j][_qp]*_test[_i][_qp]/_width[_qp];
  return jac;
}

I ran this kernel for ts and ta :
[Kernels]

  ...... some kernels solving ts and ta except convective term

  # note that the diffusion of ts must be solved in the PIPE !

  [soil_interface_with_air] 
    type                 = EAHE_Interface_Convective_Term
    variable             = ts
    exterior_temperature = ta
    block                = "PIPE"
  []

  [air_interface_with_soil]
    type                 = EAHE_Interface_Convective_Term
    variable             = ta
    exterior_temperature = ts_mean_pipe
    block                = "PIPE"
  []

[]

where "ts_mean_pipe" is an auxvariable calculated as the mean value of "ts" in PIPE (integrating in theta and r only) calculated with a "NearestRadiusLayeredAverage" user object coupled to a "SpatialUserObjectAux" auxkernel.
The results were OK. There is no problem to add some new kernels solving the 1D flowing for the air pressure and air velocity in PIPE by using some kernel having a residue of the form:
time_term*test_i   +  1D_vector_flow * _grad_test[_i][_qp](2)
since 2 (=Z) is the direction of the air flow (may be generalized by passing a flow direction vector as argument of the kernel). The thin width of the interface ensures no r dependence.
Well, I would like to thank you for all your answers, the forum keeps alive because cool developers spend some time answering newbies.
Best regards.

node.title: tensor_mechanics_J2plasticity
node.bodyText:
Hi MOOSEers,
I'm trying to do benchmark with tensor_mechanics_J2plasticity based on  [modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests/j2_plasticity/tensor_mechanics_j2plasticity.i](url). A monolithic tensile loading is applied on one surface of the cubic element, but when I check the load-displacement curve, the force does not keep increasing, instead, it decreases and shows softening after the peak load.  I also tried with [IsotropicPlasticityStressUpdate] and [ComputeMultipleInelasticStress], and the results are similar, which is confusing. Are these results correct?  Thanks.

I'm using the input file as below, with [IsotropicPlasticityStressUpdate] and [ComputeMultipleInelasticStress] for plasticity. When the external loading is relatively small, the load-displacement curve looks good, with the bi-linear region for elasticity and linear hardening, respectively. But when the loading further increases, the curve behaves wired: the hardening region becomes curved, and further the curve goes down. How to explain this? Thanks.
`[GlobalParams]
displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]
[Mesh]
[generated_mesh]
type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
elem_type = HEX8
dim = 3
nx = 1
ny = 1
nz = 1
xmin = 0.0
xmax = 1.0
ymin = 0.0
ymax = 1.0
zmin = 0.0
zmax = 1.0
[]
[cnode]
type = ExtraNodesetGenerator
coord = '0.0 0.0 0.0'
new_boundary = corner_point1
input = generated_mesh
[]
[snode]
type = ExtraNodesetGenerator
coord = '1.0 0.0 0.0'
new_boundary = corner_point2
input = cnode
[]
[]
[Variables]
[disp_x]
order = FIRST
family = LAGRANGE
[]
[disp_y]
order = FIRST
family = LAGRANGE
[]
[disp_z]
order = FIRST
family = LAGRANGE
[]
[]
[AuxVariables]
[fx]
[]
[fy]
[]
[fz]
[]
[]
[Kernels]
[./TensorMechanics]
displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
use_displaced_mesh = true
use_automatic_differentiation = true
save_in = 'fx fy fz'
[../]
[]
[BCs]
[ydisp]
type = FunctionDirichletBC
variable = disp_y
boundary = top
function = 't'
[]
[yfix]
type = DirichletBC
variable = disp_y
boundary = bottom
value = 0
[]
[./corner1_x]
type = DirichletBC
variable = disp_x
boundary = corner_point1
value = 0.0
[../]
[./corner1_y]
type = DirichletBC
variable = disp_y
boundary = corner_point1
value = 0.0
[../]
[./corner1_z]
type = DirichletBC
variable = disp_z
boundary = corner_point1
value = 0.0
[../]
[./corner2_y]
type = DirichletBC
variable = disp_y
boundary = corner_point2
value = 0.0
[../]
[./corner2_z]
type = DirichletBC
variable = disp_z
boundary = corner_point2
value = 0.0
[../]
[]
[Materials]
[strain]
type = ADComputeFiniteStrain  #ComputeSmallStrain
[]
[elasticity_tensor]
type = ADComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
youngs_modulus = 68.8e3
poissons_ratio = 0.33
[]
[./isotropic_plasticity]
type = ADIsotropicPlasticityStressUpdate
yield_stress = 320
hardening_constant = 650
relative_tolerance = 1e-8
absolute_tolerance = 1e-11
max_inelastic_increment = 0.0001
[../]
[./radial_return_stress]
type = ADComputeMultipleInelasticStress
# tangent_operator = elastic
inelastic_models = 'isotropic_plasticity'
[../]
[]
[Postprocessors]
[fx]
type = NodalSum
variable = fx
boundary = top
[]
[fy]
type = NodalSum
variable = fy
boundary = top
[]
[fz]
type = NodalSum
variable = fz
boundary = top
[]
[]
[Executioner]
type = Transient
solve_type = PJFNK
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
petsc_options_value = 'lu'
dt=0.001
dtmax=0.1
dtmin=0.001
end_time=10.0
nl_abs_tol = 1e-10
[]
[Outputs]
exodus = true
print_linear_residuals = false
[csv]
type = CSV
delimiter = ' '
file_base = 'f'
[]
[]
`
The load-displacement curve would be equivalent to an engineering stress-engineering strain relation. You'll want to plot true stress vs the logorithmic strain.
Thanks  @hugary1995 . How to plot the true stress-logorithmic strain curve for this case?

I setup the input file (see below at the end) for you. Take a look at the postprocessors, they should be self-explanatory. The stress-strain curves are shown below.


  input file
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]
[Mesh]
  [generated_mesh]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    elem_type = HEX8
    dim = 3
    nx = 1
    ny = 1
    nz = 1
    xmin = 0.0
    xmax = 1.0
    ymin = 0.0
    ymax = 1.0
    zmin = 0.0
    zmax = 1.0
  []
[]
[Variables]
  [disp_x]
  []
  [disp_y]
  []
  [disp_z]
  []
[]
[AuxVariables]
  [fx]
  []
  [fy]
  []
  [fz]
  []
[]
[Kernels]
  [TensorMechanics]
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
    use_displaced_mesh = true
    use_automatic_differentiation = true
    save_in = 'fx fy fz'
  []
[]
[BCs]
  [xfix]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    value = 0
    boundary = left
  []
  [yfix]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    value = 0
    boundary = bottom
  []
  [zfix]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    value = 0
    boundary = back
  []
  [pull]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    function = t
    boundary = front
  []
[]
[Materials]
  [strain]
    type = ADComputeFiniteStrain
  []
  [elasticity_tensor]
    type = ADComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 68.8e3
    poissons_ratio = 0.33
  []
  [isotropic_plasticity]
    type = ADIsotropicPlasticityStressUpdate
    yield_stress = 320
    hardening_constant = 650
    relative_tolerance = 1e-8
    absolute_tolerance = 1e-11
    max_inelastic_increment = 0.0001
  []
  [radial_return_stress]
    type = ADComputeMultipleInelasticStress
    inelastic_models = 'isotropic_plasticity'
  []
[]
[Postprocessors]
  [F]
    type = NodalSum
    variable = fz
    boundary = front
    execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_END'
  []
  [A0]
    type = AreaPostprocessor
    boundary = front
    execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_END'
  []
  [A]
    type = AreaPostprocessor
    boundary = front
    use_displaced_mesh = true
    execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_END'
  []
  [engineering_stress]
    type = ParsedPostprocessor
    function = 'F/A0'
    pp_names = 'F A0'
    execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_END'
  []
  [true_stress]
    type = ParsedPostprocessor
    function = 'F/A'
    pp_names = 'F A'
    execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_END'
  []
  [engineering_strain]
    type = FunctionValuePostprocessor
    function = 't'
    execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_END'
  []
  [log_strain]
    type = FunctionValuePostprocessor
    function = 'log(1+t)'
    execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_END'
  []
[]
[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = NEWTON
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu'
  automatic_scaling = true
  line_search = none
  dt = 0.005
  end_time = 2
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-08
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-10
[]
[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  csv = true
[]

As a quick sanity check: for the linear hardening law
true stress = yield stress + hardening modulus * log plastic strain
When strain is large, most portion of the total strain is plastic, hence
true stress ~= yield stress + hardening modulus * log total strain
So the true stress @ log total strain = 1 is
F/A ~= 320 + 650 * 1 = 970 MPa
The true stress we get numerically @ log strain = 1 is approximately 960 MPa.
Thanks!

@hugary1995  I used the input file you provided and got the data (below) for log strain and true stress, but the curve plotted out of it is still not a straight line, maybe I took something wrong, can you help me have a quick check? Thanks.
input_out.csv
This csv is identical to mine, which is what I used to generate the above figure.
Thank you ! @hugary1995

node.title: Variable_output vs. Material_output
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I get an unstable variable result as shown below. In addition, I also define a new property in the material which is equal to this variable.
However, when I plot them together, I find they have quite different behavior. But essentially they should be the same. What is the reason for this? Dear @GiudGiud, do you have any idea?
J

Conversion from variable to material involves a projection. I think most likely a const monomial though you should double check
This will smooth things out at output
either that or something is off for variable output but it's well tested at this point
Thanks for your help.

node.title: how to set a function that is not use on params(not x, y, z and t)

node.bodyText:
You should could do something like:
function.value(_t,  Point(a, b, c);
However, when you define the function, you have to be mindful of what depends on t, and the Point, which is essentially represented by x, y, z
You ll need to be defining a quadri-dimensional function (or just use a ParsedFunction of x,y,z)
Or you can create a user object that provides this function. If a, b, c are moose variables, you can couple them in the user object.

I agree with Yaqi. If your function has a fixed signature, just write an object for it. Depending on your specific need, it may be a user object, a material, a postprocessor, an aux kernel, etc. -- the flexibility here is the charm of MOOSE.

Yeah even for a simple expression like 'a + b + c', using a material property like a ParsedMaterial is a better idea.
If you are using AD, you must avoid using a function too unless you take care to call the ad routines on that function.
It is easier to just use material properties
Thanks all! i will try to use userobject.

node.title: u-p formulation for HM coupled analyses under dynamic conditions
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I have looked through MOOSE docs but I couldn't understand if it is possible to run coupled hydro-mechanical simulations (porous flow and solid mechanics modules, as far as I understood) under dynamic conditions, e.g. seismic actions.
In particular, the u-p formulation is a well-known one in the geotechnical community, which includes the inertial forces due to pore fluid, assumed to move together with the soil skeleton. Is something like that available in MOOSE?
Here's an abstract from Argani & Kowalczyk (2019) showing the governing equations.
Thanks,
N

I would answer that it is possible,but that there is no "user friendly" way of doing this.  By "user friendly", i mean a MOOSE Action where your input file just contains something like
[SeismicPhysics]
[]

and MOOSE magically builds all the Kernels and Materials for you.  Instead, you'll have to build those Kernels from the dynamic part of TensorMechanics, and the Kernels of PorousFlow.  In fact, you hardly need PorousFlow for this - you could use Framework Kernels - but it's probably advantageous to use PorousFlow if you can.   The reason i suggest using as much "modules" stuff is because of numerical problems.  While your equations are quite simple, they contain hidden numerical difficulties, viz the acceleration terms, which are usually damped numerically (and TensorMechanics offers a few options) and perhaps advection of the fluid, which should usually be stabilised (PorousFlow offers a few options).

node.title: Rotation matrix
node.bodyText:
Hello All
Do you know where in the codes is the place calculating the rotation matrix based on the input euler angles? which rotation convention moose uses? Does moose read in euler angles in radian or degree?
Thanks
pshen

Hello
This file and example seems to have euler angles in degrees
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/combined/test/tests/grain_texture/grn_3_rand_2D.tex
You can have a look at this code for the rotation convention (though this one is the backward way, from the matrix)
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/modules/classComputeUpdatedEulerAngle.html
This class might be informative
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/modules/classEulerAngles.html
Guillaume
TransformGenerator uses Euler angles as well for rotation. It calls a libMesh rotation function.

Hi PShen,
I assume you are asking about the rotation matrix calculation for crystal plasticity, which uses the passive rotation rather than the active rotation MOOSE uses elsewhere (to better mimic experiments).
That passive rotation used in the crystal plasticity codes is described in the documentation page here: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/crystal_plasticity/ComputeElasticityTensorCP.html . Euler angle values are expected in degrees. The original lattice rotation is stored within the member variable _crysrot[_qp].
The actual rotation matrix is computed from the Euler angles with the RotationTensor class, and the updated rotation matrix is computed with the ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityStress class here: 
  
    
      moose/modules/tensor_mechanics/src/materials/crystal_plasticity/ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityStress.C
    
    
        Lines 309 to 312
      in
      d2db894
    
  
  
    

        
          
           // Calculate crystal rotation to track separately 
        

        
          
           RankTwoTensor rot; 
        

        
          
           _elastic_deformation_gradient.getRUDecompositionRotation(rot); 
        

        
          
           _updated_rotation[_qp] = rot * _crysrot[_qp]; 
        
    
  


The ComputeUpdatedEulerAngle class Guillaume recommended can be used to read and output the update crystal orientations.
Hope this helps,
Stephanie
